thread.title: Wolves 1 Boro 3 - Report and pictures

title: Wolves 1 Boro 3 - Report and pictures
text:
David Edwards gave Wolves a first-half lead they fully merited and in the second half they continued to be the better side. 
But spurned chances and several outstanding last-ditch blocks from the visitors cost Kenny Jackett's team dearly. 
Most pertinently of the opportunities was a James Henry shot that Boro goalkeeper Dimi Konstantopoulos somehow pushed wide. 
Boro drew level 19 minutes from time through Diego Fabbrini then, with just seven left on the clock, Grant Leadbitter scored from the spot after a tired foul from Nathan Byrne on George Friend in the box. 
Wolves piled forward but couldn't find that elusive equaliser and the game was put to bed by Stewart Downing's injury-time free kick. 
A depressing afternoon was made worse by a serious looking injury to Kortney Hause, who was stretchered off in the second-half. 
Wolves made four changes from the team that lost so miserably at home to Brentford on Wednesday night. 
The suspended Dominic Iorfa made way as well as Sheyi Ojo, Adam Le Fondre and, surprisingly, James Henry. 
In came Matt Doherty, Nathan Byrne, Rajiv Van La Parra and the fit-again Edwards. 
Boro, who like Wolves came in to the game on the back of a poor recent run of form, started brightly with some gentle probing in what was a quiet opening 10 minutes. Kortney Hause of Wolverhampton Wanderers and David Nugent of Middlesbrough. 
In front of the biggest home crowd of the season of 22,008, there was a good atmosphere at Molineux with Boro also well-backed by a size-able travelling support. 
Benik Afobe, playing in a lone frontman role with Edwards behind him, got Wolves' first shhot away after wriggling clear of Daniel Ayala, but it was well wide of Dimi Konstantopoulos' goal. 
Chelsea loanee Tomas Kalas tested Emiliano Martinez' reflexes with a stunning effort 12 minutes in, with the Argentine keeper finger-tipping the rasping 20-yarder over the bar. 
Byrne, making just his second start for the club, then created a chance by himself, nicking the ball off Fernando Amorebieta by the byline and cutting inside before shooting in the side netting from a tight angle. 
The game was beginning to open up with both sides finding pockets of room in and around the respective defences. It was Edwards who found plenty of room to head Wolves in front on 22 minutes. 
Kevin McDonald set the move off, finding the overlapping Golbourne down the left with a peach of a pass. 
The left-back responded with a perfect cross towards the six-yard box where Edwards sent a diving header into the net. 
A clearly confident Edwards, who had missed Wolves' last two matches with a groin injury, tried his luck with a spectacular 20-yard volley that wasn't too far over the bar. 
Conor Coady was then booked for pulling back Emilio Nsue as Boro looked to attack. 
Just minutes later, the midfielder was extremely fortunate not to be sent off. He crashed through Kalas with a late tackle but, surprisingly, referee James Linington instead gave Coady a final warning. 
The wincing challenge could have been worthy of a red card on its own, and Coady could count himself fortunate not to earn his second red card of the season. 
Coady then saw a low shot deflected wide after more good build-up play from Wolves, which had been a feature of their first-half performance. 
Referee Linington was replaced by fourth official Darren Drysdale at half time, leading to the second-half kicking off five minutes late. 
Mr Drysdale 's yellow card was needed almost immediately when Wolves old-boy Friend scythed through Matt Doherty and was deservedly booked. 
Wolves were dealt a blow when Hause then went down with what looked like a hamstring strain. After treatment he was stretchered off, clearly in some distress. 
The injury was the last thing Jackett wanted, with Wolves already desperately shot of cover at the back. He sent on Jack Price in Hause's place with Coady moving to centre-half. 
Some rash challenges from Boro had the home fans up in arms, with Fabbrini and Fernando Amorebieta booked within a few minutes of each other. More on Wolves
